unnormalised: The Indian administrative system, with its impressive hierarchy, often leaves the common man scratching his head. Who's who and what do they do? It's more than just IAS officers, you know. Let's break down some of the most common (and sometimes confusing) titles you'll encounter.
normalised: The Indian administrative system, with its impressive hierarchy, often leaves the common man scratching his head. Who is who and what do they do? It is more than just I-A-S officers, you know. Let us break down some of the most common and sometimes confusing titles you will encounter.

unnormalised: First up, we have the classic "DM" - District Magistrate. You'll hear about them all the time, especially during elections or any kind of crisis. Essentially, they're the top dog in the district, responsible for law and order. Think of them as the CEO of a district. Then there's "SDM" - Sub-Divisional Magistrate. They report to the DM and oversee a smaller chunk of the district. It's like a regional manager in a company. Knowing this hierarchy already gives you a leg up!
normalised: First up, we have the classic D-M - District Magistrate. You will hear about them all the time, especially during elections or any kind of crisis. Essentially, they are the top dog in the district, responsible for law and order. Think of them as the C-E-O of a district. Then there is S-D-M - Sub-Divisional Magistrate. They report to the D-M and oversee a smaller chunk of the district. It is like a regional manager in a company. Knowing this hierarchy already gives you a leg up!

unnormalised: Moving on, you'll frequently see "Chief Secretary" mentioned in news related to state government decisions. The CS is the top civil servant in a state, advising the Chief Minister on policy matters. Imagine them as the COO of the state government. Important stuff! Then you have the "Under Secretary" level officials working in various departments. Think of them as the workhorses that keep the wheels turning.
normalised: Moving on, you will frequently see Chief Secretary mentioned in news related to state government decisions. unnormalised: At the central level, you'll often see the term "Joint Secretary to the Govt. of India." These officers hold significant responsibility in various ministries. They are like department heads in the central government, reporting to the Secretary of the ministry.
normalised: At the central level, you will often see the term Joint Secretary to the Government of India. These officers hold significant responsibility in various ministries. They are like department heads in the central government, reporting to the Secretary of the ministry.
